Review: In 2023, both love and death came hard on me. Death in its most penetrating yet abstract form and love in its most fervent. And how funny it is that they always arrive together. Witnessing life draining away from souls I so loved and respected but already found perished even before their true departures. And of course, love had to come then, right at that moment, and sway me left and right, from bliss to heartache in something as cliche…
Such a unique way of remembering and grieving your best friend while still excel at goofing around. Talented.
wtf the pool scenes are so well done. weird and genius!
Fabulous! Best filmmaking always finds its secret spot in porno.

Review: Does it matter that I spend so much of my time thinking about why I exist? Yes.
Kitty Zhang is truly one of a kind.
Masterful. Women, always a determined mess. And I shall prolly cherish that.
I revisit the album every couple of years whenever life gets harder than usual. And I would remember only those fleeting moments in the film. Makes me happy.
Reminds me of Takashi Ito, but very different indeed.

While it does feel like a 2h long lecture, it's undeniably one of the most unique approach to Hong Kong's past and present, in a scholarly and transdisciplinary manner. Closely following Thomas Elsaesser's claim that “one of the initial impulses of media-archaeology was to make the past strange again, rather than all too familiar” (2016:105) word by word.I like the part about miasma and the coming into existence of HK's vertical hierarchy that is as geographical as social. the…
